{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2010}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[Excellency|His Excellency]] [[Major-General|Major-General(ret'd)]] |name = George Konrote |honorific-suffix = [[Fijian honours system|OF]] [[Military Cross|MC]] |image = Jioje Konrote January 2015.jpg |office = [[President of Fiji]] |primeminister = [[Frank Bainimarama]] |term_start = 12 November 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Epeli Nailatikau]] |successor = |birth_name = Jioji Konousi Konrote |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|12|26|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Rotuma]], [[Fiji]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[FijiFirst]] |spouse = Sarote Faga Konrote |children = 2 |alma_mater = [[Natabua High School]] |religion = [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Seventh-day Adventism]] }} '''Jioji Konousi Konrote''', [[Fijian honours system|OF]], [[Military Cross|MC]], better known as '''George Konrote''' (born December 26, 1947),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=325612|title=Who is Jioje Konrote|last=Vuniwaqa|first=Bola-Bari|date=13 October 2015|publisher=[[Fiji Times]]|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref> is a [[Fiji]]an politician and retired [[Major-General]] of the [[Republic of Fiji Military Forces|Fiji Military]] who has been [[President of Fiji]] since 2015. After commanding a peacekeeping mission in [[Lebanon]], Konrote served as Fiji's High Commissioner to [[Australia]] from 2001 to 2006, as Minister of State for Immigration briefly in 2006, and as Minister for Employment Opportunities, Productivity and Industrial Relations from 2014 to 2015. He is the first non-[[Fijians|iTaukei]] president and the first to be elected by parliament, as previous presidents were selected by the [[Great Council of Chiefs]].
==Early life and military career== Konrote is a native of the island of [[Rotuma]]. His days as a pupil at [[Natabua High School]] in Lautoka, Fiji, are described in the prize-winning book on Fiji ''Kava in the Blood'' by [[Peter Thomson (diplomat)|Peter Thomson]].
A career soldier, Konrote enlisted into the [[Republic of Fiji Military Forces|RFMF]] in 1966 and trained with New Zealand and Australian defence forces, studying at institutions such as the [[Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies]] and the [[Australian Defence Force Academy]] in [[Canberra]], [[Australia]], (where he became a [[Fellow]] in 1996), and the [[Kennedy School of Government]] at [[Harvard University]] in 2000.
Rising through the ranks of the Fiji Military, he commanded battalions of Fijian soldiers in their peacekeeping efforts in Lebanon during the Fiji's [[UNIFIL]] campaign, and was subsequently appointed Deputy Force Commander of the UNIFIL operation, and finally the [[United Nations]] Assistant Secretary-General and Force Commander in Lebanon. In recognition of his contributions in these fields, Konrote was awarded the UNIFIL Peace Medal (1978), the [[Military Cross]] ([[United Kingdom|UK]], 1982), the [[Italian orders of merit|Order of Merit]] ([[Italy]], 1997), the Order of the Cedar ([[Lebanon]], 1999) and was made an Officer of the [[Order of Fiji]] (Military Division) in 1997.
==Diplomatic and political career== From 2001 to 2006, Konrote served as Fiji's [[High Commissioner]] to [[Australia]].<ref name="highcomm">(9 June 2005). [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=BBAB&d_place=BBAB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=10AA093856315E11&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Fiji envoy attends minister's funeral in Australia], ''[[BBC]] Monitoring International Reports'' (from Fijilive web site, Suva) ("Fiji's high commissioner to Australia, Maj-Gen George Konrote ....")</ref> After his appointment, equivalent to that of an [[ambassador]], expired at the end of March 2006, he was elected to represent the [[Rotuma (Rotuman Communal Constituency, Fiji)|Rotuman]] [[Communal constituencies|Communal Constituency]] in the [[Fijian general election, 2006|2006 election]],<ref name="RNZI_24130">{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=24130 |title=New Fiji MP yet to decide who to support |date=17 May 2006 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |accessdate=1 October 2011}}</ref> and he was subsequently appointed as [[Minister of State for Immigration (Fiji)|Minister of State for Immigration]] and [[Minister of State for Ex-Servicemen (Fiji)|Ex-Servicemen]] in the Cabinet of [[Laisenia Qarase]]. His role in this portfolio abruptly ended when the government was deposed in a [[2006 Fijian coup d'état|military coup]] led by [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] [[Frank Bainimarama]] on 5 December 2006.
Despite serving in the Qarase government, Konrote became a candidate for Bainimarama's party, [[FijiFirst]], in the [[Fijian general election, 2014|2014 election]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/252297/fijifirst-completes-election-candidate-list |title=FijiFirst completes election candidate list |publisher=Radio New Zealand International |date=2014-08-16 |accessdate=2014-09-24}}</ref> winning 1,585 votes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.electionsfiji.gov.fj/2014-election-results/ |title=2014 Election Results |publisher=Fiji Elections Office |date= |accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref> He was subsequently appointed as Minister for Employment Opportunities, Productivity and Industrial Relations in September 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fbc.com.fj/fiji/23196/20-member-cabinet-announced |title=20-member Cabinet announced |publisher=FBC |date=2014-09-24 |accessdate=2014-09-24}}</ref>
On 12 October 2015 Konrote resigned from Parliament after being elected as President of Fiji.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/286749/fiji-parliament-elects-new-president |title=Fiji Parliament elects new President |publisher=Radio New Zealand International |date=12 October 2015 |accessdate=15 October 2015}}</ref>
